title: Understanding Claude's Responses
description: Learn how to read and interpret Claude's code, identify what to focus on, and know when a response is good enough to use.
learningObjectives: Read Claude-generated code without needing to understand every line
Identify the key components: files, structure, dependencies
Recognize red flags and quality issues in responses
Ask effective follow-up questions to improve output

videos.title: Anatomy of a Claude Response
videos.description: Breaks down what Claude typically generates and what each part means for non-programmers.
scriptOutline: Typical response structure: explanation + file tree + code blocks
What to read first: the explanation and file tree
Key markers: 'npm install', 'create these files', 'run this command'
talkingPoints: You don't need to understand the code line-by-line — focus on the structure
Claude often explains what each file does — read those summaries
File tree shows you the skeleton of your project
Commands are usually at the end — these are action items

videos.title: Quality Checklist: Is This Response Good?
videos.description: Teaches you to spot good vs. problematic responses before wasting time implementing them.
scriptOutline: Good signs: clear file structure, step-by-step instructions, explanations for each part
Red flags: vague instructions, missing files, 'figure it out yourself' tone
When Claude says 'I can't do that' — what it means and how to rephrase
The iteration cycle: good enough → ship → improve later
talkingPoints: A good response feels like a recipe — clear steps, all ingredients listed
Bad responses leave you confused about where to start
If you're stuck, it's usually the prompt that needs fixing, not you
Perfect is the enemy of shipped — aim for 'works' first

videos.title: Follow-Up Questions That Improve Results
videos.description: Demonstrates how to iterate on Claude's responses with targeted questions.
scriptOutline: The power of 'Can you explain [specific part] for a beginner?'
Asking for alternatives: 'Is there a simpler way to do this?'
Debugging unclear instructions: 'Walk me through step 3 in more detail'
Real example: iterating on the 02Ship file structure
talkingPoints: Claude gets better the more specific your questions are
Don't accept 'create a config file' — ask what goes in it
If something seems too complex, ask for a simpler version
Good follow-ups: 'Why?', 'What does this do?', 'Can you simplify?'

textSections.title: File Structure 101
textSections.content:
When Claude generates a project, it typically creates:

**Configuration files** (package.json, tsconfig.json, .env):
- These tell tools how to run your project
- You rarely edit these manually
- Follow Claude's instructions for these exactly

**Source code** (src/, app/, components/):
- This is the actual app logic
- Organized by feature or page
- You'll iterate on these most

**Assets** (public/, images/):
- Images, fonts, static files
- You can add your own here easily

**Documentation** (README.md, .md files):
- Instructions for running the project
- Always read the README first!

textSections.title: Common Response Patterns
textSections.content:
**Pattern 1: The Full Build**
'Here's a complete Next.js app with...' → Expect 10-20 files, setup instructions

**Pattern 2: The Feature Addition**
'Add this component to your existing...' → Expect 1-5 new files, modification instructions

**Pattern 3: The Fix/Debug**
'The error is caused by...' → Expect explanation + specific code changes

**Pattern 4: The Explanation**
'Let me explain how this works...' → No code, just concepts

Knowing which pattern you're getting helps you know what to expect next.

textSections.title: Reading Code as a Non-Programmer
textSections.content:
You don't need to understand every line. Focus on:

**Function names:** `getUserData()` tells you it gets user data
**Comments:** Lines starting with // or /* explain what's happening
**Structure:** Indentation shows what's inside what
**Imports:** Top of the file shows what tools it's using

**Skip:**
- Complex logic inside functions (trust it works)
- Type definitions (TypeScript syntax)
- Advanced patterns (hooks, contexts, etc.)

Your job is to understand WHAT it does, not HOW it does it.

textSections.title: Key Definitions
textSections.content:
**Dependency:** A tool or library your project needs (listed in package.json)

**Component:** A reusable piece of UI (like a button or card)

**Route:** A page in your app (e.g., /about, /blog)

**API:** A way for different parts of your app (or other services) to talk to each other

**Environment variable:** Secret values (API keys, passwords) stored separately from code

commonMistakes.mistake: Trying to understand every line of code
commonMistakes.explanation: You don't need to! Focus on the structure and what each file does.
If you're confused, Claude will clarify — just ask!
Make sure Claude listed all files mentioned in the explanation.
The 'npm install' and 'create .env' steps are critical — don't skip them.

reflectionQuestions: Looking at Claude's response for your Lesson 1 prompt, what parts were clearest? What was confusing?
Can you identify the file structure Claude proposed? Which files are config vs. source code?
What follow-up question would you ask to improve the response you got?

exercises.title: Decode a Response
exercises.description: Take Claude's response from your Lesson 1 exercise and break it down into components.
exercises.output: A document listing: (1) All files Claude mentioned, (2) What each file does (in your own words), (3) Setup commands needed, (4) One thing you'd ask Claude to clarify
successCriteria: Described each file's purpose without copying Claude's exact words
Listed all npm/setup commands in order
Formulated at least one specific follow-up question

exercises.title: Quality Audit
exercises.description: Evaluate whether Claude's response from Lesson 1 meets quality standards.
exercises.output: Checklist with Y/N answers: Does it have clear file structure? Step-by-step instructions? Explanations for each part? Any red flags?
successCriteria: Identified at least one strength and one weakness
If weaknesses found, wrote a follow-up prompt to address them

exercises.title: Iterate on Your Prompt
exercises.description: Based on what you learned, ask Claude a follow-up question to improve your Lesson 1 response.
exercises.output: A new conversation with Claude containing: (1) Your follow-up question, (2) Claude's improved response, (3) Notes on what got better
successCriteria: Asked a specific, targeted question (not 'make it better')
Got a response that clarified or improved something
Documented what changed and why it's an improvement

instructorNotes: Common issue: Students get overwhelmed by code volume. Remind them they're managing the project, not writing it.
For live sessions: Do a live 'response audit' with a volunteer's Claude output. Crowd-source follow-up questions.
Self-paced tip: Encourage students to screenshot their file tree and annotate it with 'what this does' notes.
Time check: Exercise 3 is where real learning happens — budget extra time for Q&A.
Bonus: Show a side-by-side of a bad vs. good response to the same prompt.
